title: Understanding Cervical Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Cervical cancer begins in the cervix, the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina. It is strongly linked to persistent infection with high-risk HPV types.

Because of cervical screening programmes, many cases are detected early, and screening can identify pre-cancerous changes before cancer develops. Earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes.

items.text: Starts in the cervix
Most cases are linked to high-risk HPV infection
Screening can detect cell changes before cancer develops
HPV vaccination helps reduce risk

content.title: Remember
content.description: Regular cervical screening and HPV vaccination are important ways to reduce the risk of cervical cancer. Attending screening appointments and seeking medical advice for symptoms are key steps in prevention and early detection

content.value: Cervical cancer often develops from pre-cancerous changes in the cervical cells known as CIN (Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia). If not treated, some cases of CIN may slowly progress to cancer over many years.

items.title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
items.description: The most common type (about 70–80% of cases). It starts in the thin, flat cells on the outer surface of the cervix.

items.title: Adenocarcinoma
items.description: Begins in the glandular cells inside the cervical canal. It is less common and may be more difficult to detect with some screening methods.

items.title: Rare Types
items.description: These include neuroendocrine and other uncommon tumour types, which can behave more aggressively.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: CIN does not always develop into cancer. Regular screening and treatment of abnormal cells can prevent cervical cancer.

content.value: These factors increase risk, mainly because they affect HPV exposure or persistence:

items.text: 1. Persistent infection with high-risk HPV types
2. Smoking
3. Weakened immune system
4. Earlier exposure to HPV through sexual activity
5. Multiple sexual partners (increases likelihood of HPV exposure)
6. Long-term use of oral contraceptives (small increased risk)
7. Not attending cervical screening (abnormal cells may go undetected)
8. Some other sexually transmitted infections, which may affect HPV persistence
9. Family history (slightly increased risk)

content.title: Most Important Risk Factor
content.description: Persistent infection with high-risk HPV is the main cause of cervical cancer.

content.value: Cervical cancer may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, which is why regular cervical screening is important.

items.title: Pain or bleeding during or after sex

content.title: Important
content.description: If you experience any of these symptoms, seek medical advice.

content.value: If a cervical screening test shows abnormal results, further tests may be needed.

items.text: Colposcopy – A magnified examination of the cervix
Biopsy – A small tissue sample taken during colposcopy
Endocervical curettage (ECC) – Sometimes used to sample cells from the cervical canal
Cone biopsy – A larger tissue sample removed to confirm diagnosis or treat abnormal cells

content.value: Repeat cytology or HPV testing may sometimes be used depending on initial results.
If cervical cancer is diagnosed, imaging may be used to assess spread:

items.text: MRI
CT scan
Chest imaging

content.value: Treatment depends on the cancer type, stage, and your overall health. A specialist cancer team plans care tailored to you.
Surgery may be used in early-stage cervical cancer.

items.text: Cone biopsy (conization) – may be used for very early cancers or to preserve fertility
Simple or radical hysterectomy – removal of the uterus and cervix; lymph nodes may also be assessed
Radical trachelectomy – fertility-preserving surgery in selected early cases
Pelvic exenteration – rare, used for selected advanced or recurrent cases

content.value: For many people, especially with more advanced disease:

items.text: Radiotherapy – high-energy treatment to destroy cancer cells
Chemoradiation – chemotherapy given with radiotherapy to improve effectiveness
Chemotherapy – used in certain advanced or recurrent cases
Targeted therapy or immunotherapy – may be used in selected situations
Enhanced recovery programmes may support healing after surgery
A multidisciplinary team (surgeons, oncologists, specialist nurses) provides personalised care
Cryosurgery & LEEP → mainly CIN treatment
Hysterectomy clarified as radical/simple
Added trachelectomy (key fertility option)
Emphasised chemoradiation as core treatment, which is central in cervical cancer care

content.value: Cervical cancer is one of the most preventable cancers.
Cervical cancer is largely preventable and is often detected early through screening. Vaccination and regular cervical screening significantly reduce risk.

content.value: Cervical cancer is strongly linked to HPV and is largely preventable. Regular cervical screening and HPV vaccination offer strong protection. Because early stages may not cause noticeable symptoms, routine screening is an important way to detect cell changes before cancer develops.

items.text: Persistent infection with high-risk HPV is the main cause of cervical cancer
Screening can detect pre-cancerous changes before symptoms appear
HPV vaccination provides strong protection against high-risk HPV types
Early stages may not cause symptoms
Attending screening and follow-up appointments is important

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Cervical cancer is one of the most preventable cancers. Staying up to date with HPV vaccination, attending routine screening, and seeking medical advice for symptoms are important steps in protecting your long-term health.
